questions.question: What is the key difference in construction between a simple AC generator and a simple DC generator?

options.a: AC generators use electromagnets, while DC generators use permanent magnets.

options.c: By using more armature coils and more poles

questions.question: In a DC generator, what is the term for the rotating part and the stationary part, respectively?

questions.question: What is the purpose of the armature in a DC generator?

options.a: It is the magnetic field component.

questions.question: What are the brushes in a DC generator typically made of?

questions.question: What is a significant advantage of using AC power on aircraft?

options.a: By changing the speed of the rotor.

questions.question: What is the basic operating principle of a DC motor?
questions.explanation: A DC motor operates on the principle of electromagnetic induction. [cite: 456]

questions.question: What is the term for the tendency of a force to produce rotation in a motor?
questions.explanation: The tendency of a force to produce rotation is called torque. [cite: 512]

questions.question: The torque developed by a DC motor depends on which of the following factors?

options.a: The strength of the magnetic field and the number of turns in the coil.
options.b: The temperature and the air pressure.
options.c: The size of the brushes and the commutator.

questions.question: Which rule is used to determine the direction of rotation of a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field (motor principle)?
questions.explanation: The direction of rotation of the current carrying conductor in a magnetic field is determined by the Right-Hand Motor Rule. [cite: 542, 543, 548]

questions.question: What is the basic working principle of an AC motor?

options.a: A constant DC current in the stator induces a current in the rotor.
options.b: An alternating current in the stator windings produces a rotating magnetic field, which induces a current in the rotor.
options.c: A permanent magnet rotor rotates within a static stator field.

questions.question: What are the two main types of AC motors listed in the document?
questions.explanation: The document lists two main types of AC motors: Synchronous Motors and Induction Motors (also known as Asynchronous). [cite: 641, 642, 643]

questions.question: In an induction motor, how does the rotor speed compare to the speed of the stator's rotating magnetic field?

options.a: The rotor speed is exactly the same as the stator field speed.

questions.question: Where are three-phase induction motors typically used?

questions.question: What type of energy does a generator convert to electrical energy?

questions.question: How can magnetic flux variation be caused in a generator?

options.a: To hold the armature coils in place

questions.question: In which type of machine is the output taken from the rotating part, requiring brushes and commutators?

questions.question: What is the function of the rotor in a typical aircraft alternator?

options.a: It is the stationary power-producing component.
options.b: It is the rotating magnetic field component.
options.c: It rectifies the AC output to DC.

questions.explanation: In most aircraft alternators, the field (the magnetic field component) is the rotating part, which is called the rotor. [cite: 387, 418]

questions.question: What happens when a current-carrying conductor is placed between the poles of a magnet?

options.b: The conductor's resistance drops to zero.
options.c: The magnetic field of the conductor and the magnet interact to develop a force.

options.a: The rotor rotates at a speed slightly less than the stator field.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the split ring commutator in a simple DC generator?

options.a: To produce a sinusoidal AC waveform
options.b: To generate a pulsating DC output
options.c: To connect to an external rotator

questions.question: What is the function of the end frame in a DC generator?

options.b: To support the armature bearing and brush rings

questions.question: Why is minimizing commutation problems considered an advantage of AC power on aircraft?

options.a: AC systems do not use commutators, which can cause arcing and wear.

questions.question: What is the source of the excitation current used to supply the rotating field in most aircraft alternators?
questions.explanation: A source of direct current is used to supply the excitation current for the rotating field in an aircraft alternator. [cite: 397]

questions.question: According to the Right-Hand Motor Rule, if your index finger points in the direction of the magnetic field and your middle finger points in the direction of current flow, what does your thumb indicate?

options.a: The direction of the induced EMF
options.c: The direction of rotation of the conductor

questions.question: Which part of an AC motor generates the rotating magnetic field?

questions.question: How is the conductivity of semiconductor materials described?

options.a: Higher than conductors but lower than insulators
options.b: Lower than both conductors and insulators

questions.explanation: Semiconductors are materials whose conductivity is in between that of insulators and conductors. [cite: 732]

questions.question: What is the process of adding foreign atoms (impurities) to a semiconductor to modify its properties called?
questions.explanation: The process of adding impurities to crystals is referred to as doping. [cite: 844]

questions.question: What are the three energy bands of an atom in a solid according to the energy band theory?

options.a: Core band, Mid band, and Outer band
options.b: Conduction band, Forbidden band, and Valence band
options.c: Electron band, Proton band, and Neutron band

questions.question: How does the energy band structure of a conductor differ from that of an insulator?

options.a: Conductors have a very wide forbidden band, while insulators have a narrow one.

options.c: Conductors have an empty valence band, while insulators have a full valence band.

questions.explanation: In a conductor, the valence and conduction bands overlap, allowing electrons to move freely. [cite: 808]In an insulator, there is a large forbidden band (energy gap) between the valence and conduction bands, making it difficult for electrons to move. [cite: 805]

questions.question: What is an N-type semiconductor?

options.a: A pure semiconductor with no impurities.
options.b: A semiconductor doped with an impurity that creates an excess of holes.
options.c: A semiconductor doped with an impurity that increases the number of free electrons.

questions.explanation: When an impurity increases the number of free electrons, the doped semiconductor is a negative or N-type semiconductor. [cite: 852]

questions.question: What are the majority and minority charge carriers in a P-type semiconductor?
questions.explanation: In P-type semiconductors, holes are considered the majority carriers and electrons are the minority carriers. [cite: 906, 907]

questions.question: Impurities with 5 valence electrons, like Arsenic (As), are called what type of impurities and what do they create?

options.c: Pentavalent; they donate electrons and are called donor impurities.

questions.explanation: An impurity that has 5 valence electrons is called a pentavalent impurity. [cite: 862]They are also called donor impurities because they donate 1 electron to the doped material. [cite: 863, 864]

questions.question: What is the depletion region in a PN junction?

options.a: A region with a high concentration of free electrons and holes.
options.b: The area where the N and P regions meet, which has no free charge carriers.
options.c: The area of the P-type material only.

questions.explanation: With no externally applied potential, electrons from the N-type region cross into the P-type region and fill some holes.This forms a region with no free charge carriers called the depletion region. [cite: 1037, 1038]

questions.question: What happens to the depletion zone when a PN junction is forward-biased?
questions.explanation: Under forward-bias, holes and electrons are 'pushed' toward the junction and the depletion zone shrinks in size. [cite: 942]

questions.question: Under reverse-bias conditions, what happens to the majority carriers in a PN junction?

options.a: They are pushed toward the junction, causing a large current flow.
options.b: They are pulled away from the junction, and the depletion zone acts as an insulator.
options.c: They combine at the junction, releasing energy.

questions.explanation: In reverse-bias, holes and electrons are 'pulled' away from the junction, increasing the size of the depletion zone.The depletion zone becomes an insulator for majority carriers. [cite: 958, 959]

questions.question: A conventional diode is a unidirectional device. What does this mean?

options.a: It can only be installed in one direction.
options.b: It allows the flow of current in only one direction.

questions.explanation: A diode allows the flow of current in one direction and is also called a unidirectional device. [cite: 987]

questions.question: What are the two terminals of a diode called?
questions.explanation: The terminal on the P-type side is referred to as the anode, while the terminal on the N-type side is called the cathode. [cite: 1035, 1036]

questions.question: How is a Zener diode designed to operate?

options.b: As a variable resistor in forward bias.

questions.explanation: A Zener diode is designed to operate in the reverse bias breakdown region. [cite: 1091]

questions.question: What is a key application of a Zener diode due to its constant voltage characteristic in the breakdown region?
questions.explanation: The property of maintaining a fairly constant Zener voltage (Vz) makes it ideal for use as a voltage regulator. [cite: 1104]

questions.question: What are the three regions of a Bipolar Junction Transistor (BJT)?
questions.explanation: BJT transistors have three regions: Emitter (E), Base (B), and Collector (C). [cite: 1118]

questions.question: For a BJT to operate in the 'Active Region' for amplification, how must its junctions be biased?

options.a: Both B-E and C-B junctions must be forward-biased.
options.b: Both B-E and C-B junctions must be reverse-biased.
options.c: The B-E junction must be forward-biased and the C-B junction must be reverse-biased.

questions.explanation: In the Active Region, the B-E junction is forward biased and the C-B junction is reverse biased. [cite: 1124]

questions.question: Which BJT configuration is characterized by high input impedance, very low output impedance, and a voltage gain of approximately unity (1)?
questions.explanation: The Common-Collector (or Emitter-Follower) configuration is characterized as having high input impedance, very low output impedance, and unity voltage gain. [cite: 1134]

questions.question: What is a primary application of a transistor?

options.b: To act as an amplifier or a switch

questions.explanation: A transistor can be used as an amplifier, where small changes in base current cause big changes in collector current [cite: 1139][cite_start], or as a voltage-controlled switch[cite: 1141, 1142].

questions.question: What is required to turn a Silicon Controlled Rectifier (SCR) ON?

options.a: A negative pulse of current to the gate.
options.c: A positive pulse of current (trigger) applied to the gate while it is forward biased.

questions.explanation: An SCR is turned ON when a positive pulse of current (trigger) is applied to the gate. [cite: 1170]It conducts current only when forward biased and a triggering current is applied to the Gate. [cite: 1153]

questions.question: Once an SCR is triggered 'ON', how can it be turned 'OFF'?

options.b: By applying a larger gate current.
options.c: By anode current interruption or forced commutation (reducing anode current below the holding value).

questions.explanation: An SCR is turned OFF by two basic methods: anode current interruption and forced commutation, which involves reducing the anode current below the holding value, IH. [cite: 1171]

questions.question: What is the function of a photovoltaic device, such as a solar cell?

options.a: To change its resistance in response to light.
options.b: To convert light energy directly into DC electrical energy.
options.c: To emit light when a current passes through it.

questions.explanation: Photovoltaic cells (solar cells) convert light energy directly into DC electrical energy (voltage or current). [cite: 1187]

questions.question: How does the resistance of a photoresistor (LDR) change with increasing incident light intensity?
questions.explanation: A photoresistor's resistance decreases with increasing incident light intensity. [cite: 1198]

questions.question: How is a photodiode typically designed to operate?

questions.question: What is the primary operating principle of a Light Emitting Diode (LED)?

options.b: It heats a filament to produce light.
options.c: The recombination of electrons and holes in a forward-biased P-N junction yields a photon.

questions.question: How does a Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) pixel block light?

options.a: By generating an opaque material when voltage is applied.
options.b: By using LEDs that turn off.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common semiconductor material?

questions.question: What is an intrinsic semiconductor?

options.a: A semiconductor with an excess of electrons.
options.b: A semiconductor with an excess of holes.
options.c: A perfect, pure semiconductor crystal with no impurities.

questions.explanation: The term intrinsic is given to a perfect/pure semiconductor crystal with no impurities. [cite: 835]

questions.question: What is the barrier voltage in a PN junction?

options.a: The external voltage applied to the junction.
options.b: The voltage required to break down the junction.
options.c: An electric field across the junction that prevents further diffusion of charge carriers.

questions.question: What is a primary application of a diode as a circuit element?
questions.explanation: Diodes can be used as an ac to dc converter (rectifier). [cite: 1081]

questions.question: Which region of a BJT is very lightly doped and controls the flow of current carriers?

options.a: It operates based on the voltage applied to its gate.
options.b: A small Gate current controls a larger Anode current.
options.c: It only allows alternating current to pass.

questions.question: What is the 'holding current' (IH) of an SCR?

questions.question: What is the main difference between a photodiode and a phototransistor?

questions.question: What is a common application for LEDs in modern aircraft?
questions.explanation: LEDs designed for the visible light portion of the spectrum are useful for instruments, indicators, and even cabin lighting. [cite: 1233]High-intensity LEDs are becoming more widely used in aircraft lighting and instrument lighting. [cite: 1252]

questions.question: What is a primary application for a Common-Collector (Emitter-Follower) BJT configuration?

questions.question: What kind of device is a photoresistor?

options.b: A photoemissive device that releases electrons.
options.c: A photoconductive device that changes its resistance.

questions.question: What is an advantage of LCDs over Cathode Ray Tubes (CRTs)?
